quizName: 4. Parties involved in processing and transfers of data
introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a controller. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: Does your company's processing of personal data involve international transfers of data outside the EU/EEA or to an international organisation?

choices.selectedText: The General Data Protection Regulation does not prohibit the transfer of data outside the EEA. However, transferring data outside the EEA requires an appropriate basis for the transfer in addition to compliance with the other provisions of data protection legislation. For example, if a company processes personal data on a cloud platform provided by an organisation established outside the EEA, this constitutes a transfer of data outside the EEA. You are also required to inform the data subjects of data transfers, e.g. in your privacy statement. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/transfers-of-personal-data-out-of-the-eea
choices.selectedActions: Also remember to check whether data is being transferred by processors working on your behalf, such as cloud services. Make sure that the data subjects have been informed of the data transfers, e.g. in the privacy statement.

questions.question: If you are transferring data outside the EEA, have you specified a basis for these transfers, such as an adequacy decision made by the European Commission regarding the level of data protection in the country in question?

choices.selectedText: An adequacy decision by the Commission is the primary basis for transferring personal data to third countries. If the Commission has not issued an adequacy decision, the company must specify a different basis for the transfers, such as the standard contractual clauses approved by the Commission. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/transfers-of-personal-data-out-of-the-eea
choices.selectedActions: In certain cases, the basis for transfer does not provide sufficient protection in itself. Various technical, organisational or contractual safeguards can be used to supplement the basis for transfer in some situations. Controllers and processors who transfer data must verify on a case-by-case basis whether the legislation of the third country guarantees a level of protection essentially equivalent to that ensured within the European Economic Area for the personal data being transferred. More information on supplementary safeguards: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/safeguards-to-supplement-transfer-tools

questions.question: Have you identified all parties serving your company in the role of processor?

choices.selectedText:
The controller determines the purposes and means of processing personal data, and the processor operates according to the controller's instructions and under its supervision. Processors of personal data can include IT or software integration service providers with access to the personal data held by the controller, for example.

You should note that a controller-processor relationship is not created when a controller discloses personal data to another controller, that is, a party that intends to process the data for its own purposes (e.g. an authority). Neither are employees who process personal data as part of their duties considered processors in this sense. You need to inform the data subjects of the processors used by your company, e.g. in the privacy statement. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors
choices.selectedActions: Good. Make sure that you have informed the data subjects of the processors used by your company in your privacy statement.

questions.question: Has your company made sure that the processors commissioned by it are able to comply with the requirements of the General Data Protection Regulation?

choices.selectedText: A controller can only outsource the processing of personal data to processors who have given the controller sufficient guarantees that the processing carried out by them is compliant with the requirements of the GDPR and they have ensured that the rights of the data subjects are safeguarded. Measures refers to data protection measures, for example in information systems. The adequacy of measures must be assessed in relation to the risks of the processing. For example, a processor can demonstrate compliance with requirements to the controller by following an approved certification mechanism. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processors-responsibilities
choices.selectedActions: Good. You should keep in mind that processors have an obligation to provide the controller with all information that can be used to demonstrate compliance with the processor's obligations. The processor must also allow the controller or an auditor authorised by the controller to conduct audits of its operations, such as inspections, and participate in such audits.

questions.question: Has your company concluded processing agreements with its processors?

choices.selectedActions: Great! Companies should check that their contracts are up to date on a regular basis.

The purpose of the report generated by the tool is to give tips and recommendations.
